Appendix A. NUFFT details and influence on Biot-Savart accuracy.
Here we consider the error induced by the NUFFT tolerance on the long-range component of Biot-Savart computations. Briefly, a type-1 NUFFT can be summarised in three steps: (i) spreading values from a set of non-uniform locations onto a uniform grid using some smoothing kernel, (ii) performing a regular FFT on that grid, and (iii) undoing the spreading operation by deconvolution in Fourier space [37]. The type-2 NUFFT is the adjoint operation, roughly consisting of the same steps in opposite order. To reduce aliasing errors, the first two steps are done in a grid of $\sigma M$ points in each direction, where $M$ is the number of desired Fourier modes and $\sigma>1$ is an oversampling factor. The accuracy of the NUFFT is then determined by (i) the choice

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Fig. 6. Velocity and streamfunction errors associated to the NUFFT precision, for the test cases illustrated in Figure 2. Relative root-mean-square error of long-range filament velocity $(+)$ and streamfunction values $(\times)$ at varying NUFFT spreading widths $w$. NUFFTs are computed using the backwards Kaiser-Bessel spreading kernel (A.1) with an oversampling factor $\sigma=1.5$. Dashed lines represent an exponential decay $\sim 10^{-0.9 w}$. In all cases, the long-range cut-off parameter is set to $\beta^{(f)}=8$, ensuring subdominant cut-off errors. The Ewald splitting parameter is kept constant, $\alpha=24 / L$.
of spreading kernel, (ii) the width of the kernel (usually in number of grid points $w$ ), and (iii) the oversampling factor $\sigma[31,70,15]$. The computational complexity of a 3D NUFFT on $N$ non-uniform points can be estimated to be $O\left(w^{3} N+(\sigma M)^{3} \log M\right)$.

To evaluate NUFFTs, here we use the (backwards) Kaiser-Bessel function as spreading kernel [47, 70]. For a support in $x \in[-1,1]$, the kernel and its Fourier transform are

$$
\phi(x)=\frac{\sinh \left(\zeta \sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right)}{\pi \sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \quad \leftrightarrow \quad \hat{\phi}(k)=I_{0}\left(\sqrt{\zeta^{2}-k^{2}}\right)
$$

where $I_{0}$ is the zero-th order modified Bessel function of the first kind. The shape parameter is chosen as $\zeta=\gamma w \pi(1-1 / 2 \sigma)$ to minimise NUFFT errors [70]. Here $\gamma=0.995$ is an empirical "safety factor" [15] which slightly improves accuracy. For performance reasons, the kernel $\phi(x)$ is evaluated via a fast and accurate piecewise polynomial approximation $[15,78]$ which takes advantage of SIMD vectorisation on modern CPUs. Our NUFFT implementation [67] is written in Julia and is available on https://github.com/jipolanco/NonuniformFFTs.jl (MIT License). Compared to other existing libraries available in Julia [15, 49], our implementation allows real-valued non-uniform data, in which case it takes advantage of real-to-complex FFT routines of the FFTW library [34]. Moreover, it uses the KernelAbstractions.jl [23] package to provide a platform-agnostic GPU implementation, enabling the acceleration of vortex simulations using different kinds of GPUs.

In Figure 6, we evaluate the effect of varying the NUFFT accuracy on the relative error of long-range Biot-Savart computations, for the cases illustrated in Figure 2. Concretely, we set the oversampling factor to $\sigma=1.5$ and vary the spreading width $w$. For comparison, we compute a reference solution with $\sigma=2$ and $w=16$, which ensures that its accuracy is dominated by roundoff error. As seen in Figure 6, the relative error associated to the long-range streamfunction and velocity decay exponentially as $\sim 10^{-0.9 w}$ when using an oversampling factor $\sigma=1.5$. For $\sigma=2$, the same errors decay as $\sim 10^{-w}$ (not shown), but at the expense of costlier FFTs.

# Appendix B. Discretisation of spatial curves. 

The evaluation of the Biot-Savart law (2.2) and its local regularisation (2.4) on vortex filaments require the estimation of local tangent and curvature vectors from a set of discrete points $\left\{\boldsymbol{s}_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{N}$ representing a spatial curve. This assumes that curves can be parametrised by some sufficiently regular function $\boldsymbol{s}(\tau)$ whose derivatives on discrete locations $\tau_{j}$ (such that $\boldsymbol{s}\left(\tau_{j}\right)=\boldsymbol{s}_{j}$ ) are well defined. Furthermore, the use of quadratures to estimate line integrals (see (2.15)) requires being able to evaluate (interpolate) $\boldsymbol{s}(\tau)$ and its derivatives at any arbitrary location $\tau$. To achieve these requirements, we choose to discretise curves using parametric quintic splines. First, note that in general the nodes $\boldsymbol{s}_{j}$ are not equispaced, and that the choice of the parametrisation (the $\tau_{j}$ values) is arbitrary. We adopt the common choice of setting $\tau_{j}=\tau_{j-1}+\left|\boldsymbol{s}_{j}-\boldsymbol{s}_{j-1}\right|$ for $j \in\{2, \ldots, N\}, \tau_{1}=0$, where $|\cdot|$ represents the Euclidean distance. In this case, $\tau$ is a rough approximation of the curve arc length $\xi$, tending to $\xi$ as the number of points increases.

We consider parametric splines of order $k$ [27]. Here by convention the polynomial order is $k-1$, so that $k=4$ and 6 respectively correspond to cubic and quintic splines. The basic idea is to parametrise a spatial curve in terms of a B-spline basis,

$$
\boldsymbol{s}(\tau)=\sum_{j=1}^{N} \boldsymbol{c}_{j} b_{j}(\tau), \quad \text { for } \tau \in[0, \mathcal{T}]
$$

where $b_{j}(\tau)$ is a B-spline basis function. The basis functions are fully defined by the choice of spline order $k$ and spline knots $t_{j}$, which are a set of locations in $[0, \mathcal{T}]$. Because the curves considered here are periodic, we can simply set $t_{j}=\tau_{j}$ for all $j$ (free-ended curves would require some extra care). An important and convenient property of the B-splines is their compact support. Namely, for even $k$, the B-spline $b_{j}(\tau)$ is zero outside of the interval $\left[t_{j-k / 2}, t_{j+k / 2}\right]$.

Spline interpolation consists in determining the coefficients $\boldsymbol{c}_{j}$ given the equalities $\boldsymbol{s}\left(\tau_{i}\right)=\boldsymbol{s}_{i}$ for $i \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$. This leads to a linear system of the form $A_{i j} \boldsymbol{c}_{j}=\boldsymbol{s}_{i}$ where $A_{i j}=b_{j}\left(\tau_{i}\right)$. Thanks to the compact support of the B-splines, $\mathbf{A}$ is a cyclic banded matrix, which enables the use of specialised algorithms to efficiently solve the system. More precisely, with our choice of knots, $\mathbf{A}$ has $k-1$ bands, as well as a few out-of-bands entries in the top right and bottom left corners due to periodicity. In particular, for cubic splines $(k=4), \mathbf{A}$ is almost tridiagonal with two out-of-bands entries (one on each corner). A standard solution is to convert the system to a fully tridiagonal one using the Sherman-Morrison formula and then use the Thomas algorithm to solve the system in $O(N)$ time [86]. A similar procedure [57] can be applied to efficiently solve the cyclic pentadiagonal system arising from periodic quintic spline interpolation $(k=6)$.

The derivative of a spline $\boldsymbol{s}(\tau)$ of order $k$ is itself a spline of order $k-1$, whose coefficients $\boldsymbol{c}_{j}^{\prime}$ can be directly obtained from the coefficients $\boldsymbol{c}_{j}$ using a local differentiation formula. Moreover, splines are efficiently evaluated at locations $\tau$ using de Boor's algorithm [27]. Therefore, knowing the coefficients $\boldsymbol{c}_{j}$ one can evaluate curve positions and derivatives at any location $\tau$.

## Appendix C. Derivation of truncation error estimates.

C.1. Short-range errors. The absolute error associated to the truncation of the short-range velocity integral (3.7) at a single location $\boldsymbol{s}_{0}$ is given by

$$
\boldsymbol{v}_{\mathrm{err}}^{(\mathrm{n})}\left(\boldsymbol{s}_{0}\right)=\frac{\kappa}{4 \pi} \sum_{\boldsymbol{n} \in \mathbb{Z}^{3}} \int_{\boldsymbol{r}>\boldsymbol{r}_{\mathrm{c}}} g^{(\mathrm{n})}(\boldsymbol{r}) \frac{\boldsymbol{r} \times \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{s}}{|\boldsymbol{r}|^{3}} \quad \text { with } \boldsymbol{r}=\boldsymbol{s}-\boldsymbol{s}_{0}+\boldsymbol{n} L
$$

where the integral is over all vortex elements at a distance $|\boldsymbol{r}|=r>r_{\mathrm{c}}$ from the point $\boldsymbol{s}_{0}$. We first note that, for large $r$, the weight function $g^{(n)}(\boldsymbol{r})$ defined in (3.5) behaves as $g^{(n)}(\boldsymbol{r})=\frac{2 \alpha r}{\sqrt{\pi}} e^{-(\alpha r)^{2}}\left[1+O\left(r^{-5 / 2}\right)\right]$. Secondly, we assume that the vortices are homogeneously distributed in the spatial domain, so that the total vortex length within a spherical shell of radii $[r, r+\mathrm{d} r]$ with infinitesimal thickness $\mathrm{d} r$ is the product between the mean vortex line density and the volume of the shell, namely $\mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}=(\mathcal{L} / V)\left(4 \pi r^{2} \mathrm{~d} r\right)$. Here $\mathcal{L}$ is the total vortex length within a periodic cell of volume $V=L^{3}$. Thirdly, we assume that the orientations of the vortex elements $\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{s}$ within the shell are random and independent of the separation vector $\boldsymbol{r}$. Under these assumptions, we can formally estimate the root mean square (rms) short-range velocity error to be

$$
\varepsilon_{v}^{(n)} \approx \frac{\kappa}{4 \pi} \int_{r_{\mathrm{c}}}^{\infty} \frac{2 \alpha r}{\sqrt{\pi}} e^{-(\alpha r)^{2}} \frac{r \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}}{r^{3}}=\frac{2 \kappa \mathcal{L}}{\sqrt{\pi} \alpha V} \int_{\beta^{(n)}}^{\infty} x e^{-x^{2}} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

where $\beta^{(n)}=\alpha r_{\mathrm{c}}$. This integrates exactly to

$$
\varepsilon_{v}^{(n)} \approx \frac{\kappa \mathcal{L}}{\sqrt{\pi} \alpha V} e^{-\left(\beta^{(n)}\right)^{2}}
$$

The same procedure can be applied to the short-range streamfunction (3.6). Considering that $\operatorname{erfc}(x)=\frac{e^{-x}}{x^{3 / 2}}\left[1+O\left(x^{-2}\right)\right]$ for large $x$, one obtains the associated rms error

$$
\varepsilon_{\psi}^{(n)} \approx \frac{\kappa}{4 \pi} \int_{r_{\mathrm{c}}}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-(\alpha r)^{2}}}{(\alpha r)^{3 / 2}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}}{r}=\frac{\kappa \mathcal{L}}{\alpha^{2} V} \int_{\beta^{(n)}}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x^{2}}}{\sqrt{x}} \mathrm{~d} x=\frac{\kappa \mathcal{L}}{2 \alpha^{2} V} \Gamma\left(\frac{1}{4},\left(\beta^{(n)}\right)^{2}\right)
$$

Here $\Gamma(s, x)=\int_{x}^{\infty} u^{s-1} e^{-u} \mathrm{~d} u$ is the upper incomplete gamma function, which behaves asymptotically as $\Gamma(s, x)=x^{s-1} e^{-x}\left[1+O\left(x^{-1}\right)\right]$. Replacing this in (C.4) finally leads to the estimate

$$
\varepsilon_{\psi}^{(n)} \approx \frac{\kappa \mathcal{L}}{2 \alpha^{2} V} \frac{e^{-\left(\beta^{(n)}\right)^{2}}}{\left(\beta^{(n)}\right)^{3 / 2}}
$$

In both cases, the truncation error is dominated by the exponential decay with the square of the non-dimensional cut-off parameter $\beta^{(n)}$.
C.2. Long-range errors. The rms error associated to the long-range velocity field is defined by

$$
\left(\varepsilon_{v}^{(t)}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{V} \int_{\Omega}\left|\boldsymbol{v}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{x})-\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d}^{3} \boldsymbol{x}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{v}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{x})$ is the Fourier-truncated velocity field defined in (3.10), and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{x})$ is the non-truncated velocity field - obtained by replacing $\mathbb{K}$ with $\mathbb{K}_{\infty} \equiv\left\{\frac{2 \pi m}{L} ; m \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$ in (3.10). Using Parseval's theorem, the error can be equivalently written as

$$
\left(\varepsilon_{v}^{(t)}\right)^{2}=\sum_{\boldsymbol{k} \in\left(\mathbb{K}_{\infty} \backslash \mathbb{K}\right)^{3}}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{(t)}\right|^{2} \leq \sum_{|\boldsymbol{k}|>k_{\max }}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{(t)}\right|^{2}
$$

where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{(t)}$ are the Fourier coefficients of the long-range velocity. The last inequality results from converting from a "cubic" truncation ( $k_{i}>k_{\max }$ for each Cartesian component $i$ ) to a spherical truncation $|\boldsymbol{k}|>k_{\max }$.

In physical terms, the velocity error (C.7) can be directly related to the kinetic energy spectrum $E(k)$, defined in a periodic domain as

$$
E(k)=\frac{1}{2 \Delta k} \sum_{|\boldsymbol{k}| \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left|\dot{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right|^{2} \quad \text { for } k=m \Delta k, m \in \mathbb{N}
$$

where $\dot{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ is a Fourier coefficient of the (unsmoothed) velocity field, $\Delta k=2 \pi / L$ is the distance between two successive discrete wavenumbers, and the sum is over all 3 D wavenumbers $\boldsymbol{k}$ within the spherical shell $\mathcal{I}_{k} \equiv\left[k-\frac{\Delta k}{2}, k+\frac{\Delta k}{2}\right)$. Formally, the total kinetic energy (per unit mass) is then $E=\int_{0}^{\infty} E(k) \mathrm{d} k$. In the present context, (C.8) will allow us to quantify the effect of truncating Fourier-space computations at a certain wavenumber $k_{\text {max }}$.

At sufficiently small scales - smaller than the typical distance between vortices and the typical curvature radius of the vortices - vortex filaments can be considered as isolated straight lines. Under that assumption, one can show that the energy spectrum is $E(k)=\frac{\kappa^{2} L}{4 \pi L^{2}} k^{-1}$ for sufficiently large $k$. To see this, one can consider the energy spectrum associated to a single straight vortex. Without loss of generality, the vortex is aligned with the $z$ direction and passes through the origin, so that its length within the cubic box is $\mathcal{L}=L$ and its induced velocity field is invariant in $z$. We can thus consider the simpler problem of a point vortex in two-dimensional space. By (3.9), the Fourier coefficients of its associated vorticity field are $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}=\frac{\kappa}{L^{2}} e^{-i \boldsymbol{k} \cdot \boldsymbol{x}} \boldsymbol{e}_{z}=\frac{\kappa}{L^{2}} \boldsymbol{e}_{x}$, where $\boldsymbol{x}=(x, y)=(0,0)$ is the vortex location, $\boldsymbol{k}=\left(k_{x}, k_{y}\right)$, and $\boldsymbol{e}_{x}$ is a unitary vector. Then, the associated velocity coefficients are $\dot{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}=i \boldsymbol{k} \times \frac{\omega_{k}}{k^{2}}$, whose squared magnitudes are $\left|\dot{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right|^{2}=\frac{\kappa^{2}}{L^{4} k^{3}}$ (since $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ is orthogonal to $\boldsymbol{k}$ ). Besides, one can estimate the number of 2D Fourier modes intersecting the shell $\mathcal{I}_{k}$ to be on average $N_{k}=2 \pi m=k L$. Since $\left|\dot{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right|^{2}$ only depends on the amplitude of $\boldsymbol{k}$, one can assume that all non-zero $\dot{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ within the shell $\mathcal{I}_{k}$ are approximately equal. Replacing in (C.8), we finally obtain the energy spectrum $E(k) \approx \frac{L}{4 \pi} N_{k}\left|\dot{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right|^{2} \approx \frac{\kappa^{2}}{4 \pi L^{2}} k^{-1}=\frac{\kappa^{2} L}{4 \pi L^{2}} k^{-1}$.

This prediction is accurately verified in Figure 7 (blue curves) for the three different vortex configurations illustrated in Figure 2. Note that the relatively slow decay as $k^{-1}$ suggests that the integral of this spectrum (and thus the total energy) presents a logarithmic divergence. In fact, physically this is not the case, since the spectrum is regularised near the wavenumber $k_{a}=2 \pi / a$ associated to the vortex core size $a$, which is orders of magnitude smaller than the scales described by the VFM.

To provide an estimate of the error in the computation of the coarse-grained velocity $\boldsymbol{v}^{(\mathrm{f})}$, we now consider its associated kinetic energy spectrum $E^{(\mathrm{f})}(k)=E(k) e^{-k^{2} / 2 \alpha^{2}}=$ $\frac{\kappa^{2} L}{4 \pi V} k^{-1} e^{-k^{2} / 2 \alpha^{2}}$ for large $k$. Note that the integral of $E^{(\mathrm{f})}(k)$ is the contribution of the long-range velocity field to the total kinetic energy $E$. Examples of $E^{(\mathrm{f})}(k)$ are shown in Figure 7 for two different values of the smoothing parameter $\alpha$. In the figure, the long-range truncation is at $k_{\max }=64$ and the domain period is $L=2 \pi$. It is clear that, if $\alpha$ is too large (e.g. $\alpha L=240$ in the figure, corresponding to $\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}=k_{\max } / 2 \alpha \approx 0.84$ ), then this level of truncation is insufficient to capture the whole long-range kinetic energy. A smaller value of $\alpha$ ( $\alpha L=24$ in the figure) means that the full coarse-grained energy can be captured when truncating at the same $k_{\max }$.

Assuming the truncation wavenumber $k_{\max }$ to be sufficiently large, we can now estimate an upper bound for the absolute truncation error (C.7) associated to the

![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Fig. 7. Kinetic energy spectra associated to three different test cases. The domain period is $L=2 \pi$ and the spectra are truncated at $k_{\max }=64$ (the number of Fourier modes in each direction is $M=128$ ). Each panel shows the truncated energy spectrum associated to the unsmoothed velocity field $(\alpha L=\infty)$, as well as the energy spectra associated to two Gaussian-smoothed velocity fields $(\alpha L=240$ and 24). The spectra are normalised by the total kinetic energy $E_{\text {total }}$ obtained via (2.8). At large wavenumbers $k$, the spectra are well approximated by $E(k)=\frac{\kappa^{2} \mathcal{L}}{4 \pi V} k^{-1} e^{-k^{2} / 2 \alpha^{2}}$ (black dashed lines), where $\mathcal{L}$ is the total vortex length in each test case.
long-range velocity,

$$
\frac{\left(\varepsilon_{v}^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}}{2} \approx \int_{k_{\max }}^{\infty} E^{(\mathrm{f})}(k) \mathrm{d} k=\frac{\kappa^{2} \mathcal{L}}{4 \pi V} \int_{k_{\max }}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-k^{2} / 2 \alpha^{2}}}{k} \mathrm{~d} k=\frac{\kappa^{2} \mathcal{L}}{8 \pi V} E_{1}\left[2\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

where $E_{1}(x)=\int_{x}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-u}}{u} \mathrm{~d} u$ is the exponential integral function. For large $x, E_{1}(x)=$ $\frac{e^{-x}}{x}\left[1-\frac{1}{x}+O\left(x^{-2}\right)\right]$, and therefore $\left(\varepsilon_{v}^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2} \approx \frac{\kappa^{2} \mathcal{L}}{8 \pi V} e^{-2\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}} /\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}$. Finally, the estimated error associated to the long-range velocity field is

$$
\varepsilon_{v}^{(\mathrm{f})} \approx \kappa\left(\frac{\mathcal{L}}{8 \pi V}\right)^{1 / 2} \frac{e^{-\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}}}{\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}}
$$

A similar estimation can be done for the long-range truncation error $\varepsilon_{\psi}^{(\mathrm{f})}$ associated to the streamfunction. This is obtained by integrating

$$
\frac{\left(\varepsilon_{\psi}^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}}{2} \approx \int_{k_{\max }}^{\infty} \frac{E^{(\mathrm{f})}(k)}{k^{2}} \mathrm{~d} k \approx \frac{\kappa^{2}}{4 \alpha^{2}} \frac{\mathcal{L}}{4 \pi V} \frac{e^{-2\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}}}{\left[2\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}\right]^{2}}
$$

where we have used $\int_{x}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-u}}{u^{2}} \mathrm{~d} u=\frac{e^{-x}}{x}-E_{1}(x)=\frac{e^{-x}}{x^{2}}\left[1+O\left(x^{-1}\right)\right]$. This results in

$$
\varepsilon_{\psi}^{(\mathrm{f})} \approx \frac{\kappa}{2 \alpha}\left(\frac{\mathcal{L}}{8 \pi V}\right)^{1 / 2} \frac{e^{-\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}}}{\left(\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}\right)^{2}}
$$

Similarly to short-range errors, the long-range truncation errors are dominated by the exponential decay with the square of the cut-off parameter $\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}$. We stress that the estimates (C.10) and (C.12) are expected to be valid for sufficiently large values of $k_{\max }$ (or $\beta^{(\mathrm{f})}$ ). Furthermore, they can be expected to overestimate the actual errors due to the inequality in (C.7), which discards the contributions of some large-wavenumber modes which are actually resolved in the simulations (more precisely, a factor of $\sim 6 / \pi$ Fourier modes is discarded by the above estimates).

C.3. Combined truncation errors. To avoid unnecessary computations and achieve optimal accuracy for a given computational cost, one would like the errors associated to the short- and long-range components to be equivalent. In light of the above estimations, it seems natural to set their respective non-dimensional cut-off parameters to the same value, $\beta^{(n)}=\beta^{(\ell)}=\beta$, which also helps reducing the size of the parameter space. This finally leads to the following total truncation error estimates:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \varepsilon_{v} \approx \kappa\left[\frac{\mathcal{L}}{\sqrt{\pi} \alpha V}+\frac{1}{\beta}\left(\frac{\mathcal{L}}{8 \pi V}\right)^{1 / 2}\right] e^{-\beta^{2}} \\
& \varepsilon_{\bar{v}} \approx \frac{\kappa}{2 \alpha}\left[\frac{\mathcal{L}}{\alpha V}+\frac{1}{\beta^{1 / 2}}\left(\frac{\mathcal{L}}{8 \pi V}\right)^{1 / 2}\right] \frac{e^{-\beta^{2}}}{\beta^{3 / 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

In summary, the accuracy of the method is mainly controlled by a unique nondimensional parameter $\beta$, from which both physical- and Fourier-space cut-offs $r_{\mathrm{c}}$ and $k_{\max }$ can be obtained. This still leaves the inverse splitting distance $\alpha$ as a free parameter that can be adjusted to optimise performance (subsection 5.3).

abstract:
The Biot-Savart law is relevant in physical contexts including
electromagnetism and fluid dynamics. In the latter case, when the rotation of a
fluid is confined to a set of very thin vortex filaments, this law describes
the velocity field induced by the spatial arrangement of these objects. The
Biot-Savart law is at the core of vortex methods used in the simulation of
classical and quantum fluid flows. Naive methods are inefficient when dealing
with large numbers of vortex elements, which makes them inadequate for
simulating turbulent vortex flows. Here we exploit a direct analogy between the
Biot-Savart law and electrostatics to adapt Ewald summation methods, routinely
used in molecular dynamics simulations, to vortex filament simulations in
three-dimensional periodic domains. In this context, the basic idea is to split
the induced velocity onto (i) a coarse-grained velocity generated by a
Gaussian-filtered vorticity field, and (ii) a short-range correction accounting
for near-singular behaviour near the vortices. The former component can be
accurately and efficiently evaluated using the nonuniform fast Fourier
transform algorithm. Analytical accuracy estimates are provided as a function
of the parameters entering the method. We also discuss how to properly account
for the finite vortex core size in kinetic energy estimations. Using numerical
experiments, we verify the accuracy and the conservation properties of the
proposed approach. Moreover, we demonstrate the $O(N \log N)$ complexity of the
method over a wide range of problem sizes $N$, considerably better than the
$O(N^2)$ cost of a naive approach.
